data.title: Enable tabs by default
data.body:
After talking to @egamma we both think that tabs should be enabled by default (currently they are not). Erich rationale is that tabs is a flag ship feature that resolves a serious adoption blocker and my reasoning is that the editor stacks model is harder to understand if tabs are disabled and more natural if tabs are enabled.

@Microsoft/vscode please speak up if someone has a valid reason why we should not do that.

data.title: Extension api: process.env doesn't contain all of my .bash_profile environment variables
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code - Insiders 1.3.0-insider (a21c12346f388e51858c930875ca30968604c116, 2016-06-30T05:03:45.119Z)
- OS Version: Darwin x64 15.4.0

Steps to Reproduce:

My extension makes use of process.env to get values set in my .bash_profile. This has been working fine in VSCode 1.2 but appears to not be working in the 1.3 insider preview. My env variables set in .bash_profile are undefined on process.env in my extension.

data.title: Snippets are not always on top of the context menu
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.2.1
- OS Version: Windows 8.1

Steps to Reproduce:
1. open JS file
2. type "for" to trigger the for loop snippet or "if" or just "fun" for function

The snippet is not on top and when the "tab" button is pressed, nothing happens.

![if](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/5782506/16487776/86a09dd0-3ed5-11e6-8ca6-c916521db2d3.PNG)
![function](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/5782506/16487777/86a2c5e2-3ed5-11e6-9098-a75edfbbe33c.PNG)
![for](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/5782506/16487778/86a650f4-3ed5-11e6-8083-79d8c3f443e6.PNG)

data.title: Extensions are not npm_shrinkwrap'ed
data.body:
We have extensions that have npm dependencies, like `css` or `json`. We don't shrink-wrap them which means each build from the _same_ commit has a chance of being different.

@Microsoft/vscode

data.title: Emmet: saving a file outside the current directory in the case of using Encode/Decode command
data.body:
Help to testing #8207 

**VSCode Version**: 1.3.0-insiders (a21c12346f388e51858c930875ca30968604c116)
**OS Version**: Windows 10 Pro (build 10586.420)

**Steps to Reproduce:**
1. Open any directory and create a CSS file:
   
   ``` css
   .test { background-image: url(https://avatars1.githubusercontent.com/u/7034281?v=3&s=460) }
   ```
2. Run `Emmet: Encode\Decode`.
3. Run `Emmet: Encode\Decode` and write `../test.png`.
4. The file will be saved.

**Questions:**
1. This is correct behavior?
2. Prevent saving a file outside the current workspace? For example: `"The path **{0}** is located outside the current workspace."`
3. Provide choice to the user?

**P.S.:** This is the last problem that i could find.

data.title: Wrong deDE keybind mapping ( key: "... [" -> key: "... ü" )
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.2.1 ( 2016-06-14T12:54:38.105Z )
- OS Version: Arch Linux 4.4.14-1-lts
- Keyboard Layout: de

Problem:

VSCode shows that the keybinding is mapped to `shift+k ü`, If i press this it says no shortcut available.
However `shift+k ß` the so defined shortcut works.

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Add keybinding { key: "shift+k [", command: "cursorRight" }
2. Test in any Text-editor (expected to move right on `shift+k ü` as shown rather than `shift+k ß`)

data.title: Current open file relative path variable

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.2.1
- OS Version: Mac OS X 10.11.5 ( OS X El Capitan )

Steps to Reproduce:

I have this line in my launch json for testing just current open file:

```
{
            "name": "Test - active test file only",

            "type": "Ruby",

            "request": "launch",

            "cwd": "${workspaceRoot}",

            "program": "${workspaceRoot}/bin/rake",

            "args": [
                "test",
                "${fileBasename}" or "${file}"
            ]
        }


```

rake test needs relative path of the file. ${file} gives complete absolute path and ${fileBasename} just gives the name of the file. is there any variable to get relative path of the current open file? I want to run this script:

rake test test/integration/my_test.rb

data.title: VSC performance and feature issues when multi langage usage (ReactJS/Golang)
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.2.1
- OS Version: Ubuntu 14.04 LTS

Hello,

I'm working on an project with ReactJS/Redux and Golang respectively as frontend and backend technologies.

I started to work on the frontend part and managed to install and use `jsx` extension for a while.
Then I started to work on the backend and successfully installed and use `Go` extension.

This is when I went back to frontend that problems started. None of the previously working feature (completion, navigation, error highlighting, etc..) of the `jsx` would work anymore (Go extension still working fine though).
Moreover, when I try to force a completion for example, I just have a `Loading...` message appearing above the code and a process is started that burns 1.3GB of memory and a whole CPU charge. I need to manually kill the process, it won't kill itself on VSC quit.

`settings.json`

```
{
    //GO
    "go.buildOnSave": true,
    "go.lintOnSave": true,
    "go.vetOnSave": true,
    "go.buildTags": "",
    "go.buildFlags": [],
    "go.lintFlags": [],
    "go.vetFlags": [],
    "go.coverOnSave": false,
    "go.useCodeSnippetsOnFunctionSuggest": false,
    "go.formatOnSave": true,
    "go.formatTool": "goreturns",
    "go.goroot": "/opt/go",
    "go.gopath": "/home/emile/dev/RMTool/go",
    "go.gocodeAutoBuild": false,

    //React / JS
    "javascript.validate.enable": false,
    "editor.tabSize": 2,
    "files.trimTrailingWhitespace": true,
    // Migrated from previous "File | Auto Save" setting:
    "files.autoSave": "onFocusChange"
}
```

`.eslintrc`

```
{
  "parser": "babel-eslint",
  "extends": "airbnb",
  "env": {
    "browser": true,
    "mocha": true,
    "node": true
  },
  "rules": {
    "react/jsx-uses-react": 1,
    "react/prop-types": 0,
    "no-console": 0,
    "react/jsx-no-bind": 0,
    "react/prefer-stateless-function": 0,
    "comma-dangle": 0,
    "no-use-before-define": 0,
    "consistent-return": 0,
    "func-names": 0,
    "no-unused-expressions": 0,
    "id-length": 0,
    "no-multi-spaces": 0,
    "no-mixed-spaces-and-tabs": 2,
    "no-unused-vars": [1, {"vars": "all", "args": "none"}]
  },
  "plugins": [
    "react"
  ]
}
```

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Set a project with react and go in different folders
2. Install extensions and try out

Cheers

data.title: Find newline with regex does not highlight all matches
Tabs: Coloring issues
data.body:
Summary of collected issues for coloring in tabs
- editor find widget blends too easy into tab background in dark theme (https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/7649, https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/8294)
- we use a lot of opacity to get the different shading to work with the different themes
- people find it hard to distinguish the active tab from the inactive
- in HC theme it is hard to distinguish tabs that are in an inactive group (https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/8550)
- in HC theme the active tab shifts down (https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/8551)

Proposed solution from @bgashler1 in https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/pull/8587

data.title: Investigate removing Max results limitation for Search and replace results

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
Investigate removing Max results limitation for Search and replace results

Currently we set max limit to 2048. We need to investigate on lifting this.

data.title: Problem matcher should use unique onwer if omitted
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.3.0
- OS Version: any

Currently the owner is set to external. This can cause problems if two matchers are defined with no owner.

data.title: Installing VS Code can break DNF
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.2.1
- OS Version: Fedora 24 Kernel 4.5.5-300

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Fresh install Fedora 24
2. Install Fedy
3. Install VS Code from Fedy

When VS Code installs, it overwrites a line in `/etc/dnf/dnf.conf` from:

```
installonlypkgs=kernel installonlypkg(kernel) installonlypkg(kernel-module) installonlypkg(vm)
```

to:

```
installonlypkgs=electron
```

This causes the following error when trying to run `dnf upgrade` on `kernel`:

```
[Karai@himegoto ~] $ sudo dnf upgrade
[sudo] password for Karai: 
Last metadata expiration check: 0:47:42 ago on Thu Jun 30 01:37:33 2016.
Dependencies resolved.
Error: The operation would result in removing the booted kernel: kernel-core-4.5.5-300.fc24.x86_64.

[Karai@himegoto ~] $ sudo dnf install kernel
[sudo] password for Karai: 
Last metadata expiration check: 0:53:37 ago on Thu Jun 30 01:37:33 2016.
Package kernel-4.5.5-300.fc24.x86_64 is already installed, skipping.
Dependencies resolved.
================================================================================
 Package                   Arch        Version               Repository    Size
================================================================================
Skipping packages with conflicts:
(add '--best --allowerasing' to command line to force their upgrade):
 kernel                    x86_64      4.5.7-300.fc24        updates       70 k
 kernel-core               x86_64      4.5.7-300.fc24        updates       19 M
 kernel-modules            x86_64      4.5.7-300.fc24        updates       21 M
 kernel-modules-extra      x86_64      4.5.7-300.fc24        updates      2.2 M

Transaction Summary
================================================================================
Skip  4 Packages

Nothing to do.
Complete!
[Karai@himegoto ~] $ 
```

What VS Code should be doing is appending `electron` to the `installonlypkgs` list, not overwrite it.

data.title: ability to evaluate variables in user/workspace settings

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
The requirement is simple; provide the ability to use variables such as ${workspaceRoot} and ${env.PATH} in settings.json.

The implemented in the pull request is definitely not the right approach.
I'm looking for a more architecturally sound solution, i.e. a discussion on how to best approach this.
Also, I'm making use of the SystemVariables class (variables such as ${file} and the like will not work, infact VS Code will throw an error if such values are used)

data.title: Pinch to zoom causes UI confusion
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.3.0-insiders 798b41ab1cf3636a27042020a54ddfb4cfb8d23c
- OS Version: 10.11.5
1. Use a Mac's trackpad and the pinch to zoom gesture within a Code window
2. The content's size is heavily zoomed in or out
3. There's no obvious way to reset the zoom level

Anything I'm missing about this? If not, can we improve this or disable pinch to zoom completely?

data.title: powershell ext - processing of quoted string that contains @ doesn't recognize terminating quote
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code - Insiders 1.3.0-insider (798b41ab1cf3636a27042020a54ddfb4cfb8d23c, 2016-06-29T05:07:11.483Z)
- OS Version: Windows_NT ia32 10.0.10586

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Enter function  $next = $jsonObj.'@odata.nextlink'
2. Parser treats this as an unbalanced/unterminated string, all subsequent text color coded as string content

[example.ps1.txt](https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/files/340445/example.ps1.txt)

data.title: Investigate why configuration via symlinks no longer update
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code - Insiders 1.3.0-insider (798b41ab1cf3636a27042020a54ddfb4cfb8d23c, 2016-06-29T05:14:50.570Z)
- OS Version: Linux x64 4.4.0-24-generic, Ubuntu 16.04

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Open settings
2. Change a setting that should have an immediate impact, notice there is no change

I have a feeling this is because I have my settings.json symlinked and it's not being watched correctly.

```
❯ ls -la ~/.config/Code\ -\ Insiders/User
total 16
drwx------ 4 daniel daniel 4096 Jun 23 22:46 .
drwx------ 8 daniel daniel 4096 Jun 27 03:38 ..
drwx------ 2 daniel daniel 4096 Mar  2 10:58 snippets
drwxrwxr-x 5 daniel daniel 4096 Jun 27 02:24 workspaceStorage
lrwxrwxrwx 1 daniel daniel   47 May 21 16:20 keybindings.json -> /home/daniel/.config/Code/User/keybindings.json
lrwxrwxrwx 1 daniel daniel   44 May 21 16:20 settings.json -> /home/daniel/.config/Code/User/settings.json
```

data.title: Breakpoints in Coffeescript
data.body:
Test item #8193 
- VSCode Version: aweinand/asyncsourcemaps Code - Insiders 1.3.0-insider (392b89ffeebbc51a8574142f9629ff4a6eac15b9, 2016-06-27T22:37:58.724Z)
- OS Version: Linux x64 3.13.0-34-generic
- Coffeescript 1.10.0

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Launch config:

```
        {
            "name": "Coffee",
            "type": "node",
            "request": "launch",
            "program": "${workspaceRoot}/coffee/target.js",
            "cwd": "${workspaceRoot}/coffee",
            "sourceMaps": true,
            "stopOnEntry": false,
            "smartStep": false
        }
```
1. Coffescript:

```
log =
  warnings: 0
  warn: (args...) ->
    log.warnings++
    console.log "Warning:", args...

log.warn "There!"
```
1. Compiling with: coffee --compile --map --watch coffee/
2. Add breakpoints on at 'log.warnings++' and 'console.log ...'
3. Start debugging
4. Unexpected: The breakpoints move up by one line
5. Debugger stops at the 'log.warnings++' line
6. Unexpected: The 'args' variable is shown with value 'undefined' in the debugger and hover
7. Continue
8. Unexpected (?): The debugger stops at the 'warn: (args...) ->' line

data.title: Tab dragging should show where the tab will be inserted, not which tab it will be "replacing"
data.body:
#7854
- VSCode Version: Code - Insiders 1.3.0-insider (798b41ab1cf3636a27042020a54ddfb4cfb8d23c, 2016-06-29T05:14:50.570Z)
- OS Version: Linux x64 4.4.0-24-generic, Ubuntu 16.04

Currently:

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/2193314/16471538/4041271a-3e12-11e6-81cd-bfcded58b943.png)

It would be more intuitive for a "to be inserted here" vertical line to show up to the left of code.spec.template.

Dynamic rearranging like in Chrome would be an even nicer visual indicator.
